title: Chinese Government donates 1500 tons of rice to provide emergency relief to people affected by floods in September 2020
description: On September 17, 2020, the Chinese Government delivered a donation of 1500 tons of rice (with an estimated monetary value of $716,745) to South Sudan’s National Transitional Committee (NTC) in order to provide emergency relief to people affected by recent floods.
staff_comments: 1. To estimate the monetary value of the rice donation ($716,745), AidData takes the international price of a ton of rice in 2020 ($477.83) and multiplies it by 1,500 tons.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government donates 1500 tons of rice to provide emergency relief to people affected by floods in September 2020

# Description
On September 17, 2020, the Chinese Government delivered a donation of 1500 tons of rice (with an estimated monetary value of $716,745) to South Sudan’s National Transitional Committee (NTC) in order to provide emergency relief to people affected by recent floods.
justification: Project is humanitarian aid with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Emergency food relief, no energy or infrastructure components

title: CDB provides $500 million loan in 2020 to help Government of Sri Lanka meet its outstanding debt obligations and shore up foreign exchange reserves (Linked to Project ID#71123, #89483, and #89484)
description: On March 18, 2020, China Development Bank (CDB) and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $500 million loan agreement (foreign currency term financing facility agreement or FCTFF). The loan (ID# 4510202001100001745) carried the following borrowing terms: a 10-year maturity (estimated final repayment date: March 18, 2030), a 3 year grace period (estimated first repayment date: March 18, 2023), an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus a 2.5% margin, and an upfront (management) fee of $6,250,000. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower (the Government of Sri Lanka) to shore up official foreign reserves and meet outstanding debt obligations (i.e. repay other loans).   The FCTFF agreement was signed by Mr. S.R.Attygalle, Secretary to the Treasury on behalf of the Government of Sri Lanka and Mr. Wang Wei, Deputy Director-General, China Development Bank on behalf of the China Development Bank. The signing of the agreement was witnessed by the Hon. Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa, Chargé d'affaires of the Chinese Embassy Mr. Hu Wei, and Vice President of CDB Mr. Ma Xin. The loan fully disbursed on March 23, 2020.   The loan’s outstanding amount was $500,000,000 as of June 30, 2022.  There are some indications that this CDB loan may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. On April 12, 2022, the Government of Sri Lanka announced a ‘pre-emptive’ sovereign debt default, noting that it would suspend debt repayments to all external creditors other than multilateral institutions. Its decision to suspend external debt service reportedly affected all China Development Bank loans with amounts outstanding at the time of the announcement. As of March 2023, the Government of Sri Lanka had accumulated $338 million in arrears to China Development Bank.
staff_comments: 1. AidData has estimated the all-in interest rate (3.464%) by taking the average 6-month LIBOR rate during the month and year (March 2020) when the loan agreement was finalized (0.964%) and adding a 2.5% margin.2. The borrower signed a $1 billion FCTFF with CDB on October 12, 2018 (captured via Project ID#71123), a $500 million FCTFF with CDB on April 12, 2021 (captured via Project ID#89483), and an RMB 2 billion term facility agreement with CDB on August 17, 2021 (captured via Project ID#89484). Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Finance, Economy and Policy Development identifies the 2020 FTFF as an ‘upsizing’ of the 2018 FTFF 2018. Therefore, AidData assumes that the purposes of the 2020 FTFF and 2018 FTFF are identical. 3. The Government of Sri Lanka loan key number is 2020008.4. Some official sources refer to this CDB loan as Second Integrated Road Investment Program - Tranche 2. 5. Some official sources suggest that the loan commitment date is November 13, 2019 rather than March 23, 2020. This issue warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
GENERAL BUDGET SUPPORT

# Title
CDB provides $500 million loan in 2020 to help Government of Sri Lanka meet its outstanding debt obligations and shore up foreign exchange reserves (Linked to Project ID#71123, #89483, and #89484)

# Description
On March 18, 2020, China Development Bank (CDB) and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $500 million loan agreement (foreign currency term financing facility agreement or FCTFF). The loan (ID# 4510202001100001745) carried the following borrowing terms: a 10-year maturity (estimated final repayment date: March 18, 2030), a 3 year grace period (estimated first repayment date: March 18, 2023), an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus a 2.5% margin, and an upfront (management) fee of $6,250,000. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower (the Government of Sri Lanka) to shore up official foreign reserves and meet outstanding debt obligations (i.e. repay other loans).   The FCTFF agreement was signed by Mr. S.R.Attygalle, Secretary to the Treasury on behalf of the Government of Sri Lanka and Mr. Wang Wei, Deputy Director-General, China Development Bank on behalf of the China Development Bank. The signing of the agreement was witnessed by the Hon. Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa, Chargé d'affaires of the Chinese Embassy Mr. Hu Wei, and Vice President of CDB Mr. Ma Xin. The loan fully disbursed on March 23, 2020.   The loan’s outstanding amount was $500,000,000 as of June 30, 2022.  There are some indications that this CDB loan may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. On April 12, 2022, the Government of Sri Lanka announced a ‘pre-emptive’ sovereign debt default, noting that it would suspend debt repayments to all external creditors other than multilateral institutions. Its decision to suspend external debt service reportedly affected all China Development Bank loans with amounts outstanding at the time of the announcement. As of March 2023, the Government of Sri Lanka had accumulated $338 million in arrears to China Development Bank.
justification: The project is a financial loan for general budget support, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Loan for meeting debt obligations and shoring up foreign exchange reserves, no specific environmental or energy-related components

title: China Development Bank provides $140 million loan to Bank of Ceylon for on-lending activities in 2020
description: On June 30, 2020, the Guangxi Branch of China Development Bank (CDB) signed a long-term $140 million USD facility (loan) agreement with the Bank of Ceylon (BOC) to support on-lending activities. This credit line facility carried a maturity period of three years and a grace period of one year. The loan was to be disbursed via two, $70 million USD tranches. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to provide support needed during Sri Lanka’s fight against COVID-19; specifically, the facility was intended to supplement BOC's general lending requirements, allowing it to support businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, namely in the small and medium enterprises (SME) sector associated with exports, fishing, logistics, transport, agriculture, and manufacturing.
staff_comments: 1. Bank of Ceylon is a 100% state-owned commercial bank in Sri Lanka.
combined_text:
# Sector
BANKING AND FINANCIAL SERVICES

# Title
China Development Bank provides $140 million loan to Bank of Ceylon for on-lending activities in 2020

# Description
On June 30, 2020, the Guangxi Branch of China Development Bank (CDB) signed a long-term $140 million USD facility (loan) agreement with the Bank of Ceylon (BOC) to support on-lending activities. This credit line facility carried a maturity period of three years and a grace period of one year. The loan was to be disbursed via two, $70 million USD tranches. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to provide support needed during Sri Lanka’s fight against COVID-19; specifically, the facility was intended to supplement BOC's general lending requirements, allowing it to support businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, namely in the small and medium enterprises (SME) sector associated with exports, fishing, logistics, transport, agriculture, and manufacturing.
justification: Project involves financial services with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Loan facility for on-lending activities, general support for COVID-19 affected businesses

title: Chinese Government donates 50,000 medical masks and 1,008 diagnostic kits to Sri Lanka's Ministry of Health (Linked to Project ID#95173 and #95526)
description: On March 12, 2020, the Chinese Government announced that it would donate 50,000 medical face masks and 1,000 COVID-19 test kits to Sri Lanka. Then, on April 1, 2020, the donation of 50,000 medical masks and 1,008 nucleic acid diagnostic kits was handed over to Sri Lanka's Ministry of Health. This was the first batch of the Chinese Government's COVID-19 aid to Sri Lanka; the second batch is captured by linked Project ID#95173 and the third batch is captured by linked Project ID#95526.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates 50,000 medical masks and 1,008 diagnostic kits to Sri Lanka's Ministry of Health (Linked to Project ID#95173 and #95526)

# Description
On March 12, 2020, the Chinese Government announced that it would donate 50,000 medical face masks and 1,000 COVID-19 test kits to Sri Lanka. Then, on April 1, 2020, the donation of 50,000 medical masks and 1,008 nucleic acid diagnostic kits was handed over to Sri Lanka's Ministry of Health. This was the first batch of the Chinese Government's COVID-19 aid to Sri Lanka; the second batch is captured by linked Project ID#95173 and the third batch is captured by linked Project ID#95526.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical masks and diagnostic kits for COVID-19 response, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Government donates 20,000 test kits, 10,000 KN95 masks, 100,000 surgical masks, 10,000 PPE coveralls, 1,000 goggles, and 50,000 gloves to Sri Lanka's Ministry of Health (Linked to Project ID#95172 and #95526)
description: On April 27, 2020, the Chinese Government donated 20,000 test kits, 10,000 KN95 masks, 100,000 surgical masks, 10,000 personal protective equipment (PPE) coveralls, 1,000 protective goggles, and 50,000 surgical gloves to Sri Lanka's Ministry of Health. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation. Hu Wei, the Chargé d'affaires of the Chinese Embassy, attended the ceremony and delivered the supplies to Pavithra Wanniarachchi, the Sri Lankan Health Minister.   This was the second batch of the Chinese Government's COVID-19 aid to Sri Lanka; the first batch is captured by linked Project ID#95172 and the third batch is captured by linked Project ID#95526.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates 20,000 test kits, 10,000 KN95 masks, 100,000 surgical masks, 10,000 PPE coveralls, 1,000 goggles, and 50,000 gloves to Sri Lanka's Ministry of Health (Linked to Project ID#95172 and #95526)

# Description
On April 27, 2020, the Chinese Government donated 20,000 test kits, 10,000 KN95 masks, 100,000 surgical masks, 10,000 personal protective equipment (PPE) coveralls, 1,000 protective goggles, and 50,000 surgical gloves to Sri Lanka's Ministry of Health. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation. Hu Wei, the Chargé d'affaires of the Chinese Embassy, attended the ceremony and delivered the supplies to Pavithra Wanniarachchi, the Sri Lankan Health Minister.   This was the second batch of the Chinese Government's COVID-19 aid to Sri Lanka; the first batch is captured by linked Project ID#95172 and the third batch is captured by linked Project ID#95526.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of test kits, masks, PPE, and other medical equipment to support healthcare system

title: Chinese Embassy donates 125,000 face masks to Sri Lankan students in May 2020
description: On May 26, 2020, the Chinese Embassy in Sri Lanka donated 125,000 face masks to Sri Lanka's Ministry of Education. These masks were intended to be distributed to lower-income families across Sri Lanka on the occasion of the lifting of the two-month curfew and the imminent reopening of schools.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Embassy donates 125,000 face masks to Sri Lankan students in May 2020

# Description
On May 26, 2020, the Chinese Embassy in Sri Lanka donated 125,000 face masks to Sri Lanka's Ministry of Education. These masks were intended to be distributed to lower-income families across Sri Lanka on the occasion of the lifting of the two-month curfew and the imminent reopening of schools.
justification: Project is a humanitarian donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of face masks for public health purposes, targeted at lower-income families and students
